title: Election of DCEs will help reduce poverty – Local government expert
text:
Source: Ghana | Adom News I Abednego Asante Asiedu I abednego.asante-asiedu@adomonline.com |Twitter:@Abednegoasante Date: 08-10-2015 Time: 06:10:30:am 
The Dean of Studies and Research at the Institute of Local Government Studies, Dr. Eric Oduro Osae, has added his voice to calls that parliament should consider reviewing the relevant sections of the constitution to ensure that Ghanaians elect all members of the district assemblies and DCEs to reduce the high rate of poverty in the country. 
According to him, the election of the Metropolitan, Municipal and District Chief Executives (MMDCEs) will push them to work harder to develop their districts assemblies. 
Ghana’s democracy is attractive to the international community because of the country’s decentralisation policy, where power of governance is vested in the local community to govern its own affairs. 
Many African countries have come to Ghana to study the decentralisation policy to help grow their own democracies. 
But a section of the public believe that the appointment of MMDCEs by the President is not helping the development of the nation. 
Recently, a survey carried out by the National Commission for Civic Education (NCCE) indicated that majority of Ghanaians favour the election of Metropolitan, Municipal and District Chief Executives against the current practice of appointment by the President. 
The survey which was carried out in September 2014 in 72 districts across the country showed that 69.4 per cent of respondents wanted to go to the polls to elect their own local leaders. 
Apart from the survey, most local governance experts, political analysts and some politicians believed that the appointment of DCE to the Assemblies will enable the state progress as expected by all citizenry. 
Speaking Wednesday on Adom FM’s “Burning Issues” programme with Afia Pokua on the recent Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) 2015 report, Dr. Eric Oduro Osae said if these MMDCEs are are elected, they will work to satisfy the electorate. 
The MDGs report revealed that proportion of the poor are far away from escaping poverty, 
“The assemblies who are presently constituted continue to be hostage to central government through the power of appointment by the President. This should be scrap and should be elected to deepen Ghana’s democracy to develop local economy,” Dr. Oduro Osae stated. 
He added that the appointment of DCEs make some of them arrogant. He said they usually do not work in the interest of the people as a result of this. 
Meanwhile, Country Director of development NGO SEND-Ghana, George Osei-Bimpeh, has also called on the various assemblies to be affective whenever they are being appointed into office by a sitting President and stop the politicization of developmental projects. 
He added that the assemblies must use the common fund wisely and effective for the betterment of the nation.
